content.text: The Constitution is the supreme law of the land. It creates the framework for the federal government and protects certain rights.

items: Written in 1787; ratified by the states
Creates three branches: Legislative, Executive, Judicial
Includes the Bill of Rights (first 10 amendments)

content.text: These amendments protect individual freedoms such as speech, religion, press, assembly, and due process.

items: 1st: Freedoms of speech, religion, press, assembly, petition
4th: Protection from unreasonable searches and seizures
5th: Due process; protection against self-incrimination
6th: Fair and speedy public trial
10th: Powers not given to the federal government are reserved to the states or the people

content.text: Makes laws. Congress has two parts: the Senate and the House of Representatives.
Enforces laws. Led by the President; includes the Vice President and the Cabinet.
Interprets laws. The Supreme Court and other federal courts.

materials.title: How a Bill Becomes a Law (Simple Steps)

items: A member of Congress introduces a bill.
A committee studies, revises, and votes on it.
The full chamber debates and votes.
The other chamber repeats the process.
Both chambers pass the same version.
The President signs it (or vetoes; Congress can override with enough votes).
Federal: national defense, foreign policy, money supply.
State: education standards, driver licensing, many public health rules.
Local (city/county): policing, fire services, local roads, libraries, parks.

content.text: Common regions include Northeast, South, Midwest, and West.

items: Northeast: Maine to Pennsylvania
South: Florida to Texas and up to Kentucky
Midwest: Ohio to the Dakotas
West: Rockies to the Pacific Coast, plus Alaska and Hawaii
Compass directions: North, South, East, West
Legend/Key: explains symbols
Scale: turns map distance into real distance (e.g., 1 inch = 10 miles)

content.text: Tip: If the map has no compass, assume the top is north.

materials.title: Economics: Needs vs. Wants; Goods vs. Services

items: Needs: things required to live (food, water, shelter).
Wants: nice to have (toys, entertainment).
Goods: physical items you can touch.
Services: actions someone does for you (haircut, bus ride).
